definition: A classification system categorizing melanomas into nine distinct pathways based on cumulative sun damage (CSD), cell of origin, and molecular alterations.
clinical: Varies by pathway. Includes tumors on intermittently sun-damaged skin (low CSD), heavily sun-damaged skin (high CSD), acral sites, mucosal sites, and congenital nevi.
pathogenesis:
Categorized into 9 pathways:
1. Low CSD (superficial spreading, BRAF V600E).
2. High CSD (lentigo maligna, NRAS/BRAF non-V600E/NF1).
3. Desmoplastic Melanoma (High CSD, specific molecular signature).
4. Spitz Melanoma (HRAS, kinase fusions).
5. Acral Melanoma (Amplifications/deletions, not UV-associated).
6. Mucosal Melanoma (Amplifications/deletions, not UV-associated).
7. Melanoma arising in Congenital Nevus (NRAS).
8. Melanoma arising in Blue Nevus (GNAQ/GNA11).
9. Uveal Melanoma (GNAQ/GNA11).
macroscopic: Variable depending on pathway (e.g., lentiginous patches on sun-damaged skin vs. acral lesions).
microscopic: Histopathology does not always perfectly correspond to the pathway (e.g., melanomas on sun-damaged skin may still arise from a nevus).
ancillary_studies: Molecular testing (NGS, CGH) used to classify pathways.
prognosis_and_prediction: Dependent on stage and molecular pathway. High mutation burden (High CSD) often associated with better response to immune checkpoint blockade. BRAF V600E tumors may respond to BRAF/MEK inhibitors.

related_figures.legend: Diagram of the WHO pathways to melanoma. (Time: 340s)
Progression model from normal melanocyte to nevus to melanoma. (Time: 518s)

definition: A benign melanocytic neoplasm consisting of dendritic melanocytes located in the dermis, driven by G-protein signaling mutations.
clinical: Typically presents as a blue to gray papule or nodule.
pathogenesis:
Activated by mutations in the G-alpha-q signaling pathway. 
Mutations (mutually exclusive): GNAQ (most common), GNA11, PLCB4, CYSLTR2.
microscopic:
Conventional: Dendritic melanocytes and melanophages in the dermis, typically without a junctional component. 
CYSLTR2-mutated variant: Intradermal, spindled melanocytes, distinct morphology different from conventional blue nevus.
ancillary_studies: Genetics: GNAQ, GNA11, PLCB4, CYSLTR2 mutations. BAP1 expression is retained (loss suggests malignancy in this context).
differential_diagnosis: Malignant Blue Nevus (Melanoma arising in Blue Nevus) - characterized by BAP1 loss.
prognosis_and_prediction: Benign. However, melanoma arising in blue nevus (GNAQ+ with BAP1 loss) is aggressive.

related_figures.legend: Conventional blue nevus with dendritic melanocytes. (Time: 586s)
CYSLTR2 mutated blue nevus showing distinct spindled morphology. (Time: 820s)
Example of malignant progression: GNAQ mutated tumor with BAP1 loss. (Time: 3238s)

definition: A benign or intermediate melanocytic neoplasm characterized by large epithelioid and/or spindled melanocytes, driven by kinase fusions or HRAS mutations.
clinical: Pink to red papule or nodule. Can present with nodal deposits (nodal nevi), which are benign.
pathogenesis:
Initiating alterations:
1. HRAS mutations (<25%).
2. Kinase Fusions (ALK, ROS1, NTRK1, NTRK3, RET, BRAF, MET). 
Fusions lead to constitutive activation of the kinase domain.
microscopic:
General: Large nests, junctional component, clefting around nests, Kamino bodies. 
HRAS-mutated (Desmoplastic): Thickened collagen bundles, predominantly intradermal, fascicles of melanocytes, 'school of fish' pattern, may have dermal mitoses. 
ALK-fused: Plexiform, fascicular, 'raining down' pattern, broad and percolating. 
BRAF-fused: Can show large nests, fibrosis, and inflammation; may mimic melanoma.
ancillary_studies:
IHC: ALK (positive in ALK fusions), ROS1 (positive in ROS1 fusions), NTRK1 (requires titration). 
CGH: Gain of 11p (HRAS), Gain of 7p (BRAF). 
NGS: Detection of fusions (requires tiling introns).
prognosis_and_prediction: Generally benign. Nodal deposits can occur (nodal nevi) and do not represent metastasis. BRAF fusions may be a therapeutic target if malignant transformation occurs.

related_figures.legend: HRAS mutated Spitz nevus with junctional component and inflammation. (Time: 1810s)
Desmoplastic Spitz nevus showing fascicles and trapped collagen. (Time: 1852s)
ALK-fused Spitz tumor with plexiform, raining-down fascicles. (Time: 2530s)
Nodal deposit of Spitz nevus (HRAS mutated) initially concerned for metastasis. (Time: 1292s)

definition: An intermediate melanocytic tumor (melanocytoma) defined by the loss of BAP1 expression, often arising within a common nevus.
clinical: Enlarging black papule or orange-ish/brown elevated papule arising within a nevus. Can be sporadic or associated with BAP1 Tumor Predisposition Syndrome (increased risk of uveal melanoma, mesothelioma, RCC).
pathogenesis:
Two-hit mechanism:
1. Initiating mutation: BRAF V600E (common) or NRAS Q61.
2. Inactivation of BAP1: Loss of function mutation + deletion of 2nd allele (e.g., loss of chromosome 3).
macroscopic: Exophytic, dome-shaped, distinct color change from background nevus.
microscopic:
Biphasic population: 
1. Conventional nevus component: Small cells, scant cytoplasm.
2. BAP1-inactivated component: Large epithelioid melanocytes, abundant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei (plasmacytoid/rhabdoid), distinct cellular outlines. Scattered lymphocytes often present.
ancillary_studies:
IHC: BAP1 (nuclear loss in large epithelioid cells). 
Genetics: BRAF V600E positive (typically). CGH shows loss of chromosome 3 (BAP1 locus).
differential_diagnosis: Atypical Spitz Tumor (historically categorized as such), Melanoma, Halo Nevus.
prognosis_and_prediction: Intermediate biological potential, though generally indolent. Patients with germline mutations require screening for other malignancies (eye, kidney, lung).

related_figures.legend: Epithelioid melanocytes with abundant cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. (Time: 2756s)
Biphasic population: Large epithelioid cells vs small common nevus cells. (Time: 2784s)
IHC showing nuclear loss of BAP1 in the large melanocytes. (Time: 3130s)
